title: How to Pickle Asparagus

steps.headline: Select the freshest asparagus you can find for crunchy pickles.
steps.description: To test if your asparagus is fresh, try to snap it in half. It should break cleanly without any strings attached to the broken ends. If the asparagus is stringy or limp, that’s another sign that it’s probably not fresh. Selecting medium to thick asparagus will also give extra crunch to the finished pickles.

steps.headline: Wash 7 canning jars in hot soapy water.
steps.description: Although some pickling recipes call for sterilized canning jars, if you boil the jars in a canner for at least ten minutes, you don’t need to sterilize the jars. Washing them in hot soapy water will do. Rinse them thoroughly afterwards. Wide-mouthed jars work best because they are easier to fill with asparagus spears. If you pickle your asparagus using the refrigerator instead of a canner, be sure to sterilize your jars by boiling them in hot water for at least 10 minutes. You can also place the lids in a pan of water over medium-low heat until you are ready to seal the jars.

steps.headline: Put 3 cloves of garlic and ½ tsp (1 g) mustard seed at the bottom of each jar.
steps.description: Dry off your washed canning jars with a clean, dry dish towel. Add the spices to the bottom of the jar before you add the asparagus spears. For extra dill flavor, add ¼ teaspoon (.5 g) of dill to each jar as well. For spicy pickles, add ⅛ teaspoon (.3 g) red chili flakes to each jar.

steps.headline: Wash the asparagus and cut them to fit in the jars.
steps.description: Wash the asparagus under cool water and trim them. To do this, place the spears on a cutting board and slice off the bottom part of each spear where the green starts to fade to white with a sharp kitchen knife. Discard the tough white ends. Cut the spears to fit into your canning jars. Make sure to leave about 1 inch (2.5 cm) space between the asparagus and the top of the jar. If you are using small, pint-sized jars, you can simply cut the asparagus spears in half. If you find you are having to trim just a little off the asparagus to get them to fit in your jars, save the extra little pieces you’ve trimmed off for stir fry or soup.

steps.headline: Pack the asparagus spears into your jars as tightly as you can.
steps.description: Place your asparagus pieces in the jars all facing the same way. You may find once you put them in that you will have to trim some to make sure there is about 1 inch (2.5 cm) between the asparagus tips and the top of the jar. Keep the heads and the stems in different jars if you want to keep the heads for guests or special occasions.

steps.headline: Bring the vinegar, water and salt to a simmer in a large pot.
steps.description: Add 10 cups (2,400 ml) apple cider vinegar, 10 cups (2,400 ml) cups water, and 1 cup (296 g) canning salt in a pot. Cover the pot and bring the mixture to a boil on high heat. Then, reduce the heat to medium-high and leave it to simmer for at least three minutes.

steps.headline: Pour the hot brine into the jars.
steps.description: Carefully pour the hot brine over the asparagus in the jars. Pour directly from the pot or use a ladle for more control. Fill each jar up until ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) from the top. Wipe the rims with a paper towel. If there are any air bubbles in the jars, you can remove them by swirling a chopstick through the bubble until it dissipates.

steps.headline: Screw the lids onto the jars.
steps.description: Take the lids out of the hot water bath and dry them. Then, screw them onto the jars. Be sure not to make them too tight.

steps.headline: Bring the canner to a boil and set the jars on the wire rack.
steps.description: While you wait for the canner to boil, arrange your jars to fit on the wire rack. A water boiling canner is safer and more effective than simply putting the cans into boiling water. It keeps the jars separated (so they don’t accidentally break), and away from the bottom of the pot. This lets the hot water circulate all the way around the cans.

steps.headline: Place the rack onto the pot and boil the jars for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Use hot pads to grab the handles of the wire rack. Slowly lower it so it’s sitting on the bottom of the canner. The jars should be covered by at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water. Keep an eye on the canner to make sure it maintains a steady boil. Leave the jars in the boiling water for 10 minutes. Let the jars boil for 15 minutes for elevations from 1,000–6,000 feet (300–1,830 m)

steps.headline: Turn off the heat and lift the rack out.
steps.description: Carefully lift out the rag by the handles using hot pads. Set it on the edge of the pot. Remove the jars one at a time. Place them on a dry dish towel. Take jars out opposite of one another to prevent the rack from falling over.

steps.headline: Let the jars cool for at least 24 hours.
steps.description: Let the jars sit undisturbed on the counter for at least 24 hours. Then, store them in a cool, dry place. Pickled asparagus made using a canner will hold for up to 1 year.

steps.headline: Pickle asparagus in the refrigerator for an easier option or if you don’t have a canner.
steps.description: Instead of pickling the asparagus in a canner, boil the brine along with the garlic cloves and spices in a big pot for 3-5 minutes. Pour the hot mixture over the asparagus. Wait until the jars cool to room temperature and then put them in the refrigerator. Leave them for at least one week before eating. Asparagus pickled in the refrigerator will keep for at least 1 month.

text: Preparing the Asparagus Select the freshest asparagus you can find for crunchy pickles. To test if your asparagus is fresh, try to snap it in half. It should break cleanly without any strings attached to the broken ends. If the asparagus is stringy or limp, that’s another sign that it’s probably not fresh. Selecting medium to thick asparagus will also give extra crunch to the finished pickles. Wash 7 canning jars in hot soapy water. Although some pickling recipes call for sterilized canning jars, if you boil the jars in a canner for at least ten minutes, you don’t need to sterilize the jars. Washing them in hot soapy water will do. Rinse them thoroughly afterwards. Wide-mouthed jars work best because they are easier to fill with asparagus spears. If you pickle your asparagus using the refrigerator instead of a canner, be sure to sterilize your jars by boiling them in hot water for at least 10 minutes. You can also place the lids in a pan of water over medium-low heat until you are ready to seal the jars. Put 3 cloves of garlic and ½ tsp (1 g) mustard seed at the bottom of each jar. Dry off your washed canning jars with a clean, dry dish towel. Add the spices to the bottom of the jar before you add the asparagus spears. For extra dill flavor, add ¼ teaspoon (.5 g) of dill to each jar as well. For spicy pickles, add ⅛ teaspoon (.3 g) red chili flakes to each jar. Wash the asparagus and cut them to fit in the jars. Wash the asparagus under cool water and trim them. To do this, place the spears on a cutting board and slice off the bottom part of each spear where the green starts to fade to white with a sharp kitchen knife. Discard the tough white ends. Cut the spears to fit into your canning jars. Make sure to leave about 1 inch (2.5 cm) space between the asparagus and the top of the jar. If you are using small, pint-sized jars, you can simply cut the asparagus spears in half. If you find you are having to trim just a little off the asparagus to get them to fit in your jars, save the extra little pieces you’ve trimmed off for stir fry or soup. Pack the asparagus spears into your jars as tightly as you can. Place your asparagus pieces in the jars all facing the same way. You may find once you put them in that you will have to trim some to make sure there is about 1 inch (2.5 cm) between the asparagus tips and the top of the jar. Keep the heads and the stems in different jars if you want to keep the heads for guests or special occasions. Making the Brine Bring the vinegar, water and salt to a simmer in a large pot. Add 10 cups (2,400 ml) apple cider vinegar, 10 cups (2,400 ml) cups water, and 1 cup (296 g) canning salt in a pot. Cover the pot and bring the mixture to a boil on high heat. Then, reduce the heat to medium-high and leave it to simmer for at least three minutes. Pour the hot brine into the jars. Carefully pour the hot brine over the asparagus in the jars. Pour directly from the pot or use a ladle for more control. Fill each jar up until ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) from the top. Wipe the rims with a paper towel. If there are any air bubbles in the jars, you can remove them by swirling a chopstick through the bubble until it dissipates. Screw the lids onto the jars. Take the lids out of the hot water bath and dry them. Then, screw them onto the jars. Be sure not to make them too tight. Pickling and Storing the Asparagus Bring the canner to a boil and set the jars on the wire rack. While you wait for the canner to boil, arrange your jars to fit on the wire rack. A water boiling canner is safer and more effective than simply putting the cans into boiling water. It keeps the jars separated (so they don’t accidentally break), and away from the bottom of the pot. This lets the hot water circulate all the way around the cans. Place the rack onto the pot and boil the jars for 10 minutes. Use hot pads to grab the handles of the wire rack. Slowly lower it so it’s sitting on the bottom of the canner. The jars should be covered by at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water. Keep an eye on the canner to make sure it maintains a steady boil. Leave the jars in the boiling water for 10 minutes. Let the jars boil for 15 minutes for elevations from 1,000–6,000 feet (300–1,830 m) Turn off the heat and lift the rack out. Carefully lift out the rag by the handles using hot pads. Set it on the edge of the pot. Remove the jars one at a time. Place them on a dry dish towel. Take jars out opposite of one another to prevent the rack from falling over. Let the jars cool for at least 24 hours. Let the jars sit undisturbed on the counter for at least 24 hours. Then, store them in a cool, dry place. Pickled asparagus made using a canner will hold for up to 1 year. Pickle asparagus in the refrigerator for an easier option or if you don’t have a canner. Instead of pickling the asparagus in a canner, boil the brine along with the garlic cloves and spices in a big pot for 3-5 minutes. Pour the hot mixture over the asparagus. Wait until the jars cool to room temperature and then put them in the refrigerator. Leave them for at least one week before eating. Asparagus pickled in the refrigerator will keep for at least 1 month.
sentences: Preparing the Asparagus Select the freshest asparagus you can find for crunchy pickles.
To test if your asparagus is fresh, try to snap it in half.
It should break cleanly without any strings attached to the broken ends.
If the asparagus is stringy or limp, that’s another sign that it’s probably not fresh.
Selecting medium to thick asparagus will also give extra crunch to the finished pickles.
Wash 7 canning jars in hot soapy water.
Although some pickling recipes call for sterilized canning jars, if you boil the jars in a canner for at least ten minutes, you don’t need to sterilize the jars.
Washing them in hot soapy water will do.
Rinse them thoroughly afterwards.
Wide-mouthed jars work best because they are easier to fill with asparagus spears.
If you pickle your asparagus using the refrigerator instead of a canner, be sure to sterilize your jars by boiling them in hot water for at least 10 minutes.
You can also place the lids in a pan of water over medium-low heat until you are ready to seal the jars.
Put 3 cloves of garlic and ½ tsp (1 g) mustard seed at the bottom of each jar.
Dry off your washed canning jars with a clean, dry dish towel.
Add the spices to the bottom of the jar before you add the asparagus spears.
For extra dill flavor, add ¼ teaspoon (.5 g) of dill to each jar as well.
For spicy pickles, add ⅛ teaspoon (.3 g) red chili flakes to each jar.
Wash the asparagus and cut them to fit in the jars.
Wash the asparagus under cool water and trim them.
To do this, place the spears on a cutting board and slice off the bottom part of each spear where the green starts to fade to white with a sharp kitchen knife.
Discard the tough white ends.
Cut the spears to fit into your canning jars.
Make sure to leave about 1 inch (2.5 cm) space between the asparagus and the top of the jar.
If you are using small, pint-sized jars, you can simply cut the asparagus spears in half.
If you find you are having to trim just a little off the asparagus to get them to fit in your jars, save the extra little pieces you’ve trimmed off for stir fry or soup.
Pack the asparagus spears into your jars as tightly as you can.
Place your asparagus pieces in the jars all facing the same way.
You may find once you put them in that you will have to trim some to make sure there is about 1 inch (2.5 cm) between the asparagus tips and the top of the jar.
Keep the heads and the stems in different jars if you want to keep the heads for guests or special occasions.
Making the Brine Bring the vinegar, water and salt to a simmer in a large pot.
Add 10 cups (2,400 ml) apple cider vinegar, 10 cups (2,400 ml) cups water, and 1 cup (296 g) canning salt in a pot.
Cover the pot and bring the mixture to a boil on high heat.
Then, reduce the heat to medium-high and leave it to simmer for at least three minutes.
Pour the hot brine into the jars.
Carefully pour the hot brine over the asparagus in the jars.
Pour directly from the pot or use a ladle for more control.
Fill each jar up until ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) from the top.
Wipe the rims with a paper towel.
If there are any air bubbles in the jars, you can remove them by swirling a chopstick through the bubble until it dissipates.
Screw the lids onto the jars.
Take the lids out of the hot water bath and dry them.
Then, screw them onto the jars.
Be sure not to make them too tight.
Pickling and Storing the Asparagus Bring the canner to a boil and set the jars on the wire rack.
While you wait for the canner to boil, arrange your jars to fit on the wire rack.
A water boiling canner is safer and more effective than simply putting the cans into boiling water.
It keeps the jars separated (so they don’t accidentally break), and away from the bottom of the pot.
This lets the hot water circulate all the way around the cans.
Place the rack onto the pot and boil the jars for 10 minutes.
Use hot pads to grab the handles of the wire rack.
Slowly lower it so it’s sitting on the bottom of the canner.
The jars should be covered by at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) of water.
Keep an eye on the canner to make sure it maintains a steady boil.
Leave the jars in the boiling water for 10 minutes.
Let the jars boil for 15 minutes for elevations from 1,000–6,000 feet (300–1,830 m) Turn off the heat and lift the rack out.
Carefully lift out the rag by the handles using hot pads.
Set it on the edge of the pot.
Remove the jars one at a time.
Place them on a dry dish towel.
Take jars out opposite of one another to prevent the rack from falling over.
Let the jars cool for at least 24 hours.
Let the jars sit undisturbed on the counter for at least 24 hours.
Then, store them in a cool, dry place.
Pickled asparagus made using a canner will hold for up to 1 year.
Pickle asparagus in the refrigerator for an easier option or if you don’t have a canner.
Instead of pickling the asparagus in a canner, boil the brine along with the garlic cloves and spices in a big pot for 3-5 minutes.
Pour the hot mixture over the asparagus.
Wait until the jars cool to room temperature and then put them in the refrigerator.
Leave them for at least one week before eating.
Asparagus pickled in the refrigerator will keep for at least 1 month.
